text:
If they nailed down the package manager, that would be a really good appeal - "this code will run everywhere, and fast".

That's not something you can say about a lot of ecosystems 5/10/30 years down the line.

elements.text:
If they nailed down the package manager, that would be a really good appeal - "this code will run everywhere, and fast".

dx

text: Others can probably chime in that the worst pain points of Fortran were likely symptoms of the age - no easy test suite integrations, no package management for handling deps and installs, and a bad, bad culture of physicists just making do with tghe bare minimum coding skills.

elements.text: Others can probably chime in that the worst pain points of Fortran were likely symptoms of the age - no easy test suite integrations, no package management for handling deps and installs, and a bad, bad culture of physicists just making do with tghe bare minimum coding skills.

text: no idea. I heard in a talk recently that Rust has basically the same compiler guarantees about arrays that Fortran has, so there's no reason Rust can't reach fortran speeds with enough effort.

text: the dependancy resolver problem is actually widely extinsable to a lot of other problems. Having a generic optimal framework for solving that problem would be useful for a lot of stuff. I've run into a problem involving it in a programming language design (using this as a proxy to try to solve a problem in physics).
